title: Les Fusselman
text:
Lester Leroy Fusselman (March 7, 1921 – May 21, 1970) was an <a href="Americans">American</a> <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> player, a <a href="catcher">catcher</a> who appeared in 43 <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League</a> <a href="games%20played">games</a> for the – <a href="St.%20Louis%20Cardinals">St. Louis Cardinals</a>. He threw and batted <a href="right-handed">right-handed</a>, stood tall and weighed .
Born in <a href="Pryor%2C%20Oklahoma">Pryor, Oklahoma</a>, Fusselman graduated from <a href="Payson-Seymour%20High%20School">Payson-Seymour High School</a> in <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a> and attended <a href="Western%20Illinois%20University">Western Illinois University</a>. His decade-long professional career, which began in the Cardinal <a href="farm%20system">farm system</a> in 1942, was interrupted by three years of service in the <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. Fusselman's postwar baseball career was spent bouncing between upper-level Redbird affiliates until, at age 31, he made the Cardinal roster in 1952 as a <a href="rookie">rookie</a>. He appeared in 32 games that season as the backup catcher to <a href="Del%20Rice">Del Rice</a>, who started 137 out of the Cards' 154 games. Fusselman himself <a href="at%20bat">batted</a> 63 times and made ten <a href="hit%20%28baseball%29">hits</a>. On May 9, 1952 he went two for four with a <a href="home%20run">home run</a> and two <a href="runs%20scored">runs scored</a> off <a href="Ken%20Raffensberger">Ken Raffensberger</a> of the <a href="Cincinnati%20Reds">Cincinnati Reds</a>.
As a <a href="minor%20league%20baseball">minor leaguer</a>, Fusselman <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batted</a> .274 with 717 hits in 823 games played. His playing career ended after the 1954 season.
